title: Riot, Your Reasoning for Never Wanting to Make Sandbox Mode is Ridiculous
body: "Just playing a game of League is all the practice you need" is what you're basically saying. That's like saying "You can't just shoot free throws, just play a full game of basketball." No, I'm sorry but that is some of the worst logic I've ever seen from game devs.

What's interesting to me is the potential of a well made sandbox mode from a business perspective seems incredible.

Imagine a sandbox mode alongside a Scenario Creators akin to Age of Empires or  StarCraft. On the one hand, die hard competitive players get to improve at an unprecedented rate, investing more time (and hoepfully money) into the system. If you're worried about a Bronze player feeling even more bronze, readjust the ladder system to rebalance the amount of players in each tier of play.

But where the real money would be is in the solo scenario generator. Imagine a tower defense game with the LoL cast, or a single (or multi!) player campaign, steeped in lore about your favorite champion. Imagine how many casual, and I emphasize this market, players would love this kind of content?

Now imagine how much money a first party, official, scenario or campaign would bring in? How much are customers willing to pay to play through a campaign about Teemo, Vayne, Draven, or Katarina? Five dollars a chapter? One dollar a mission? This is a giant stack of cash waiting to be scooped up. And it solves problems in the process!

(So please, steal my idea, take ALL the money I just made you, and invest in servers for the replay system of our dreams!)

> While there are very real skills one can develop in a hyperbolic time chamber, we never want that to be an expectation added onto an already high barrier to entry. On an individual level, we know this isn’t always true – some just want a space to practice flashing over walls without having to wait at least 3.6 minutes in between – but when that benefit is weighed against the risk of Sandbox mode ‘grinding’ becoming an expectation, we just can’t accept the tradeoff.

That's the part that gets me; Sandbox mode grinding *is* already an expectation for many players, just instead of sandbox mode you just load up a custom and wait the downtime anyways. I've spent hours loading into custom games by myself just to practice CSing, flash mechanics, etc. because it's more efficient that loading into a game, hoping I get the role/champion I want to practice, and trying a lvl 3 Flash + Q as Vi and oh look, I messed up and fed the enemy top double buffs and now they're snowballing out of control and I have to wait another 20+ minutes to queue up for another game to try another lvl 3 Flash + Q gank.

That's the thing about this game; they don't want people grinding? *The game is already a grind*. You grind for IP for champions and runes. You grind in solo q every day to try to rank up. Heck, in every game you're grinding for CS in order to buy your first few items to even begin to play the actual game.

I don't think a decent 'sandbox mode' would even take that much effort. If they added a "Cheats Enabled" box (something that many games have) when setting up custom games with like, four options (Infinite gold, EXP gain off including minions/monsters staying the same strength, 90% CDR including summoners, mana/energy costs off), that would solve most of people's issues as far as practice goes. It's basically just URF mode with the ability to change some settings.

Honestly I'm not that miffed that they're not working on a sandbox mode; customs and bot games work decent enough for practice. I also don't see grinding in a Sandbox mode becoming an expectation; if players aren't willing to do it in customs or bot games (or even normals), where you're playing the game still, I don't see those players jumping into a dedicated game mode to practice CSing or flash mechanics. I just can't make sense of the reasoning "We don't want you grinding in sandbox mode, so go grind in normal games"

I think the real reason is also the reason why they're not going to make URF a permanent part of the game, or why they hardly put work in Dominion or 3v3; it pulls too much attention away from your standard 5v5 summoner's rift.

Must it really be spelled out for you? Why is it that 100% of the fighting games have a practice mode? Why is it that majority of the top tier players practice in practice/sandbox mode than vs CPUs?

Testing out builds against what? So Sandbox mode has custom bots that you build any way you want? That sounds reasonable and totally not a waste of time, especially considering how many different ways to build there are. While you think this will help you test out builds, the usefulness of that experience is pretty much moot. So much complexity in build paths such as power spikes, farming time, the opposing team composition, early game dominance or failure, etc. mean that testing out a final build in Sandbox mode do nothing other than let you play with whatever toys you have. Every game of League is different and every build path you decide on must be tailored to fit the situation, so it's better to learn from Normals than Sandbox.

Dodging and aiming skillshots can be done simply enough in a custom game with one other friend (I doubt the AI for this mode would be incredibly realistic, but we can dream). The only problem would probably be cooldowns, but aside from ultimates and flashes there is no huge difference.

Having a better understanding of minion control comes best from a custom game with either friends or normals. True experience in this can only come from actually playing against another human being who is also trying to control the minion wave, unless we have an AI specifically tailored to controlling the minion wave.

Adjusting variables to better understand outcomes... how the hell is this supposed to work. There's a million variables in every teamfight, split second to split second, which are much easier to theorize than adjust ingame.

Practicing mechanics without the hindrance time. Like what? Aiming a Rumble ultimate? Flashing a wall? There are other champions who can help with flash mechanics training such as Lucian (Relentless Pursuit), Graves (Quickdraw), and Ekko (Phase Dive), all with dashes that pass terrain and travel 425-325 units (Flash is 425 units). Reactive Barriers? Janna and Lulu can help with that. What mechanics are you talking about, because if these were essential you would have found a way around them.

Fighting games have practice modes because it's a 1 on 1 battle; there are less variables affecting everything there. League is a lot more strategically complex, while mechanically simpler, so it doesn't all come down to whether you got that extra hit in on your lane opponent, but it does come down to whether you've responded to the enemy's build paths and team composition accordingly. This comes down to theory rather than practice. If you really need to practice EVERY TOPLANE MATCHUP POSSIBLE, find a friend and play a custom.

In conclusion, Sandbox mode isn't a necessity, not because it doesn't generate profit but because it sucks resources out of any other area which actually needs improvement. You can claim that it wouldn't take any time at all, that they can just hire and setup a whole new division to cater to this one specific need, but it just doesn't matter.

While I do believe that a Sandbox Mode would be extremely useful for some people that actually want to take advantage and practice a few things, I don't think their reasoning is really wrong.

There are many things I would love to practice without having to wait for dumb things like "Cooldowns," A very common one, which walls you can jump over on specific champs with their abilities. Or which walls are actually flashable, And then find out the perfect spot to actually use that ability to get across terrain quickly. It'd be great to practice these things. 

**I think it'd be great to _practice a few things._**

But I believe that this may create a situation that is current in those Co-op vs AI games. 

I have some people I know (and used to know) that played **nothing but** games that were not Summoners Rift, mostly Co-op vs AI players. Their reasoning, like many others, is because they knew they were preform terribly in a real game, so they decided to keep hiding in Co-op vs AI games and other games modes, hoping to improve in the game in those game modes. 

Now I'm not saying there's a problem with this,  but no player that actually _wants_ to improve will gain anything from anything that's not a real Summoners Rift game. This being said, I'm sure it can be related back into Sandbox Mode. People may create a way of thinking, that they will suddenly get good at the game just from spending time in **Sandbox Mode** which, remember, is **_not a real game of League of Legends._** Just like the other game modes, people may just get sucked into this one and never come out, and if they do, they would not have gained as much experience as they could have gained if they played a real match. 

People might think by spending a lot of time in Sandbox Mode, that they will improve just because they learned a few more mechanics on a few champions, but being able to apply that to a real game is what is much more important if you want to improve. 

The main point of that was, people should not have to rely too much on Sandbox Mode, because it may end up just trapping people inside this new gamemode and no progress would be made. 

**But this isn't the only problem that may occur**

A little quick one, a problem that may come up with Sandbox mode, is that it might be too much fun! I'm sure it has to (or should be) like customs, and you can invite and have people join you. This will just create a bunch of people playing Sandbox Mode in customs, and instead of actually doing what Riot (probably) intended for, has now become a new fun gamemode for everyone to play in, instead of it being a place where you can practice skills. Which leads into less people getting sucked into customs and Co-op vs AI games and also not creating a person's skill progression.

(Please keep in mind I assume that people who play League of Legends actually want to improve, though I know there are a few who purely play for fun, my perspective League of Legends is being a place where people want to get better at the game, and have fun when you know how to play the game)
